Really? Java's do:

lang.Object)

> Speaking of lists, how can this notation be expanded for use in
testing
> lists? While Hamcrest's current support for lists seems somewhat
> spotty-I haven't used it too, too much so I could be wrong-it has the
> capability to be expanded to provide robust support for lists. Using
a
> Hamcrest-like notation, NUnit allows you to say things like this:
>
>
>
> Assert.That( iarray, Has.No.Null );

With JUnit's matchers, this can be

assertThat(iarray, each(notNullValue());

> Assert.That( iarray, Is.Unique );

I'm not aware of a built-in matcher for this one, but it could be
written.

> Assert.That( iarray, Has.All.GreaterThan(0) );

With the full hamcrest library and JUnit:

assertThat(iarray, each(greaterThan(0)));

> Assert.That( iarray, Has.Some.GreaterThan(2) );

assertThat(iarray, hasItem(greaterThan(2)));

> You'll notice that in this case, we are mixing matchers (Is/Has,
> All/No/Some, GreaterThan, and Null) in order to test this list using
> matchers that are not named after functions on the list under test.
> You'll also notice that the mixing of the matchers allows us to
produce
> rather powerful combinations that are not necessarily foreseen by the
> JUnit developers. Will this new notation support such extensions as
> well?

I guess it could, but I'm not sure yet it should. The typing gets
rough. Continued thoughts appreciated.

David Saff
